The Elder Who Gave Half a Robe
“The Fortunate One Padumuttara’s
disciple named Sujāta;
Searching for a rag-robe,
he was wandering in the dust-heap.
In the city of Haṁsavatī,
I was a servant to another;
having given half a robe,
I bowed down with my head.
By that good deed well done,
by the intention and the vow,
having given up the human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.🔽Thirty-three times I was Sakka,

analyzed: tettisa khattum devindo  deva rajjam akārayi
translated: the King of the Gods,
and seventy-seven times
I was a King who rules the world.
A vast regional kingdom,
incalculable in number,
by the gift of half a robe,
I rejoice, being fearless.
And if I so wished today,
with the forests and the mountains,
I could cover it with robes,
the fruit of giving half a robe.
For a hundred thousand aeons,
the gift I gave then,
I do not know of a bad destination,
the fruit of giving half a robe.
I have burned up the defilements,
I live without defilements.
How welcome it was for me
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.
